user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    status = pthread_cond_broadcast(&impl->cv);
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarBroadcast_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No suspicious fragments found. Reasoning:
- The function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token, and there is no assignment to token anywhere in the function (no modifications to the pointer itself).
- The macro is invoked as OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(..., *token). Macro expansion yields &tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(*token))], and &(*token) is equivalent to token; this uses the address-of and dereference operators but does not modify the pointer parameter.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const OS_object_token_t * and only reads token->obj_idx; it does not modify the object or the pointer.
- impl is an lvalue local variable receiving the address of an entry from OS_impl_condvar_table; assigning that address does not alter the function parameter.
- The call to pthread_cond_broadcast(&impl->cv) passes the condition variable from the table; modifying the condition variable object (via pthread) is allowed by the rule because the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified. In any case, the function parameter token itself is not modified.
Given these points, there are no places in the provided code where the function parameter token or the pointer itself is modified, so no fragments require investigation for violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
